p: 6. Our goal is not “subjective” or “common” worlds of meaning but the essential structure of meaning as such. Meaning is a characteristic of human beings alone. But someone might object: If every human being has “his or her own world,” then the world of meaning becomes “subjective” and we lose a “common” world of meaning.
Our focus is not on either subjective or common worlds of meaning but on the essence of meaning—the world of meaning as such. How might we encounter that?
